[[Knight Grand Commander of the Order of the Star of India]] | relations= | laterwork= }} [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] '''Sir Neville Bowles Chamberlain''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|GCB|GCSI}} (10 January 1820 – 17 February 1902) was a senior [[British Indian Army|Indian Army]] officer. He fought at the [[Battle of Ghazni]] in July 1839 during the [[First Anglo-Afghan War]], the [[Gwalior Campaign#The Battle of Maharajpore|Battle of Maharajpur]] in December 1843 during the [[Gwalior Campaign]] and the [[Battle of Chillianwala]] in January 1849 and the [[Battle of Gujrat]] in February 1849 during the [[Second Anglo-Sikh War]]. During the [[Indian Rebellion of 1857|Indian Rebellion]] he served as [[Adjutant-General (India)|Adjutant-General of the Indian Army]] and was severely wounded at the [[Siege of Delhi]] in July 1857. He went on to be Commander-in-chief of the [[Madras Army]] in February 1876 and was sent on a mission to the [[List of monarchs of Afghanistan|Emir of Afghanistan]], [[Sher Ali Khan]], whose refusal to allow him to enter the country precipitated the [[Second Anglo-Afghan War]] in November 1878. ==Military career== Chamberlain was born the third son of [[Sir Henry Chamberlain, 1st Baronet]], [[consul general]] and [[charge d'affaires]] in [[Brazil]], and his second wife Anna Eugenia née Morgan.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/32352 |title=Chamberlain, Neville Bowles|publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|accessdate=6 October 2013}} His elder brother, [[William Charles Chamberlain]], was an admiral, while younger brothers [[Crawford Chamberlain]], and Charles Francis Falcon Chamberlain, were also army officers. Chamberlain initially entered the [[Royal Military Academy, Woolwich]] but was withdrawn after a year and was commissioned as an [[ensign (rank)|ensign]] in the [[Bengal Native Infantry]] on 24 February 1837.Heathcote, p. 83 He fought at the [[Battle of Ghazni]] in July 1839 as well as other engagements during the [[First Anglo-Afghan War]] and was wounded on several occasions.{{LondonGazette|issue=20136|supp=|startpage=2395|date=6 September 1842|accessdate=6 October 2013}}{{LondonGazette|issue=20136|supp=|startpage=2397|date=6 September 1842|accessdate=6 October 2013}} Promoted to [[lieutenant]] on 16 July 1842, he transferred to the 1st Cavalry of [[Shah Shujah Durrani|Shah Shujah]]'s Contingent and took part in a march from [[Kandahar]] to [[Kabul]] in August 1842.{{LondonGazette|issue=20168|supp=|startpage=3410|date=24 November 1842|accessdate=6 October 2013}} During the [[Battle of Kabul (1842)#Final evacuation|withdrawal from Kabul]] he was again wounded at [[Landi Kotal]] in October 1842 and again at [[Ali Masjid]] in November 1842. He became attached to the Governor-General's Bodyguard in January 1843 and took part in the [[Gwalior Campaign#The Battle of Maharajpore|Battle of Maharajpur]] in December 1843 during the [[Gwalior Campaign]]. Chamberlain became military secretary to the [[List of Governors of Bombay|Governor of Bombay]] in late 1846 and then brigade major with the Bengal Irregular Cavalry in 1848.Heathcote, p. 84 He took part in the [[Battle of Chillianwala]] in January 1849 and the [[Battle of Gujrat]] in February 1849 during the [[Second Anglo-Sikh War]]. He became assistant adjutant-general of the Sirhind division in May 1849 and, having been promoted to [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] in the 16th Bengal Native Infantry on 1 November 1849 and to brevet [[major]] on 2 November 1849,{{LondonGazette|issue=21048|supp=|startpage=3766|date=11 December 1849|accessdate=6 October 2013}} he became assistant commissioner in the [[Rawalpindi District]] in December 1849 and then assistant commissioner in the [[Hazara District]] in June 1850. Promoted to [[lieutenant-colonel]] on 28 November 1854, he was given the command of the Punjab Irregular Frontier Force and led several expeditions against the frontier tribes. During the [[Indian Rebellion of 1857|Indian Rebellion]] he served as [[Adjutant-General (India)|Adjutant-General of the Indian Army]] and was severely wounded at the [[Siege of Delhi]] in July 1857.{{LondonGazette|issue=22095|supp=|startpage=673|date=10 February 1858|accessdate=6 October 2013}} For this he was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] on 11 November 1857{{LondonGazette|issue=22064|supp=|startpage=3851|date=17 November 1857|accessdate=6 October 2013}} and promoted to [[colonel]] on 27 November 1857.{{LondonGazette|issue=22828|supp=|startpage=1347|date=4 March 1864|accessdate=6 October 2013}} [[File:1857 cashmeri gate delhi.jpg|thumb|left|Scene following the Siege of Delhi, at which Chamberlain was severely wounded, during the Indian Rebellion]] Chamberlain was reappointed to the command of the Punjab Irregular Frontier Force in 1858 and led it during the [[Ambela Campaign]] during which he was again severely wounded again in November 1863. Advanced to [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] on 11 April 1863,{{LondonGazette|issue=22727|supp=|startpage=2069|date=17 April 1863|accessdate=6 October 2013}} he returned to the United Kingdom and was promoted to [[major-general]] for distinguished service on 5 August 1864.{{LondonGazette|issue=23130|supp=|startpage=3653|date=26 June 1866|accessdate=6 October 2013}} He was appointed a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Star of India]] on 24 May 1866 and accompanied the [[Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|Duke of Edinburgh]] on an official trip to India in 1869. He was promoted to [[lieutenant-general]] on 1 May 1872,{{LondonGazette|issue=23865|supp=|startpage=2667|date=7 June 1872|accessdate=6 October 2013}}{{LondonGazette|issue=23876|supp=|startpage=3196|date=16 July 1872|accessdate=6 October 2013}} advanced to [[Knight Grand Commander of the Order of the Star of India]] on 24 May 1873{{LondonGazette|issue=23979|supp=|startpage=2584|date=24 May 1873|accessdate=6 October 2013}} and further advanced to [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] on 28 May 1875.{{LondonGazette|issue=24213|supp=|startpage=2851|date=29 May 1875|accessdate=6 October 2013}} Chamberlain became Commander-in-chief of the [[Madras Army]] in February 1876 and, having been promoted to full [[general]] on 1 October 1877,{{LondonGazette|issue=24552|supp=|startpage=750|date=15 February 1878|accessdate=6 October 2013}} was sent on a mission to the [[List of monarchs of Afghanistan|Emir of Afghanistan]], [[Sher Ali Khan]], whose refusal to allow him to enter the country precipitated the [[Second Anglo-Afghan War]] in November 1878. He was a member of the [[Madras Legislative Council (1861–91)|Madras Legislative Council]] and, for several months, acting military member of the council of the [[Governor-General of India]].{{LondonGazette|issue=24276|supp=|startpage=6467|date=17 December 1875|accessdate=6 October 2013}} He left India in February 1881 and retired to [[Lordswood, Southampton|Lordswood]] near [[Southampton]] in February 1886.{{LondonGazette|issue=25564|supp=|startpage=1029|date=2 March 1886|accessdate=6 October 2013}} In retirement Chamberlain was an active member of the [[General Assembly of Unitarian and Free Christian Churches|Southampton Unitarian Church]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uua.org/uuhs/duub/articles/fmnevillechamberlain.html |title=Field Marshal Sir Neville Chamberlain|publisher=Unitarian Universalist Association|accessdate=6 October 2013}} He was promoted to [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|field marshal]] on 25 April 1900, died at Lordswood on the 17 February 1902{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Death of Sir Neville Chamberlain |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=19 February 1902 |page_number=10 |issue=36695| }} and was buried at [[Rownhams]] near Southampton. ==Family== In 1873 Chamberlain married Charlotte Cuyler Reid, daughter of [[Major-general (United Kingdom)|Major-General]] [[William Reid (British Army officer)|Sir William Reid]], who died in 1896; there were no children. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|last=Heathcote|first=Anthony|title=The British Field Marshals 1736 - 1997|year=1999|isbn= 0-85052-696-5}} ==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Neville Bowles Chamberlain |sopt=t}} *{{Cite EB1911|short=x|wstitle=Chamberlain, Sir Neville Bowles}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Frederick Haines|Sir Frederick Haines]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Madras Army|C-in-C, Madras Army]]|years=1876–1880}} {{s-aft|after=[[Frederick Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts|Sir Frederick Roberts]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chamberlain, Neville Bowles}} [[Category:1820 births]] [[Category:1902 deaths]] [[Category:British military personnel of the First Anglo-Afghan War]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Second Anglo-Sikh War]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Indian Rebellion of 1857]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Knights Grand Commander of the Order of the Star of India]] [[Category:British field marshals]] [[Category:British East India Company Army officers]] [[Category:British Indian Army generals]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Umbeyla Campaign]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Gwalior Campaign]] [[Category:Commanders-in-chief of Madras]] [[Category:Members of the Madras Legislative Council]] [[Category:Unitarian Universalists]]
